page.title: 01 LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Within our area is Woad Lane, Long Sutton. We believe that woad was grown and processed down this lane. Woad is the name of the dye or mordant and is also given to the plant from which the dye is taken. Isatis tinctoria (the woad plant) is a biennial herb, that is a herb that has only leaves in the first year of growth and then flowers and seeds in the second year, when it grows from 60 cms to 1.5 m high. The plant produces a blue dye, although a fresh bath would give a deep black shade. Cloth was dyed green in the Middle Ages by dyeing it blue and then afterwards yellow with weld, another dye obtained from a plant. A lady told our teacher that from photographs she had seen she thinks the woadmill was situated just east of Hovell's pit, Woad Lane.
